definition: to talk about this and that (idiom); to ramble incoherently
east/host (i.e. sitting on east side of guest)/landlord
surname Dong
to pull/to play (a bowed instrument)/to drag/to draw/to chat
the West/abbr. for Spain 西班牙[Xi1 ban1 ya2]/Spanish
west
to pull/to tear/(of cloth, thread etc) to buy/to chat/to gossip/(coll.) (Tw) ridiculous/hokey

sentences.english: His grandfather roamed over the earthquake in Tangshan for a long time.
sentences.chinese: 他的祖父東拉西扯地談了半天唐山的地震。

sentences.english: Most people are talking randomly and actually have no true goal.
sentences.chinese: 大多數人總是東拉西扯的毫無真正的目標。

sentences.english: What is she rambling on about?
sentences.chinese: 她在東拉西扯些什麼呢？

sentences.english: He beat about the bush for a half hour without coming to the point.
sentences.chinese: 他東拉西扯地談了半小時不到一點。

sentences.english: The old woman rambled on about her misfortunes.
sentences.chinese: 這位老太婆談起她的不幸遭遇東拉西扯地說個沒完。

sentences.english: When you ramble on about topics it is more likely that you are losing your audience.
sentences.chinese: 如果你東拉西扯會讓聽衆失去興趣。

sentences.english: Remember to limit yourself to about 30 seconds without rambling on and on.
sentences.chinese: 切記限定自己在30秒內完成表述，不要東拉西扯。

sentences.english: He blathered on for hours about at this morning's meeting.
sentences.chinese: 在今天上午的會議上他東拉西扯了好幾個鐘頭。

sentences.english: Stop beating around the bush and tell us who won.
sentences.chinese: 別再東拉西扯了，告訴我們是誰贏了。

sentences.english: He stalled off the truth with rambling.
sentences.chinese: 他東拉西扯的把真相支吾過去了。

sentences.english: Stop beating around the bush and tell me who won.
sentences.chinese: 不要東拉西扯了，告訴我誰贏。

definition: to shoot without aim (idiom); fig. to speak without thinking/firing blindly/to shoot in the air/a shot in the dark
sequel/continuation of a book
to invent crazy nonsense/to cook up (excuses)/to talk at random/wild babble
to display one's slight skill before an expert (idiom)
to amuse oneself/to play with/to tease
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
pleasure seeking (idiom); life of dissipation
to argue strenuously or with sophistry/to quibble
complete nonsense (idiom)
dumbstruck and unable to reply (idiom); left speechless/at a loss for words
old school/conservative faction
polite phrase/conventional greetings/cliché/to try to worm facts out of sb
video program
vocal accompaniment in some traditional Chinese operas/to speak in support of/to chime in
